title: R41254
content: The Department of Defense was funded by continuing resolutions until FY2011. On April 15, 2011, an omnibus funding bill for the balance of FY2011 was signed, providing $659.9 billion for DOD activities, a reduction of $18.2 billion from the President's request. Additionally, $17.8 billion was provided for DOD's military construction budget, a reduction of $2.2 billion from the President's request. H.R. 1473 incorporated $4.4 billion in reductions to the President's DOD budget, including cuts to various spending categories and major weapons programs. Notable reductions included $1.7 billion from the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter program, $473 million from a new ground combat vehicle for the Army, and $325 million from a new mid-air refueling tanker for the Air Force. The FY2011 National Defense Authorization Act, H.R. 1473, made cuts to the President's DOD budget but also added funds for various programs including Navy strike fighters, National Guard equipment, medical research, Israeli missile defense, and Military Career Advancement Account. The bill did not allocate funds for the development of an alternate engine for the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter. The House version of the bill authorized $725.9 billion, $2.7 million less than requested, while the Senate version authorized $725.7 billion, a reduction of $240.7 million. The Senate did not act on S. 3454, which would have repealed the "don't ask, don't tell" policy for military service. A compromise version of the authorization bill (H.R. 6523) was signed into law on January 7, 2011 (P.L. 111-383), supporting President Obama's budget request. The enacted H.R. 6523 supported President Obama's position by not adding funds to continue production of the C-17 cargo plane. It authorized a 1.4% increase in basic pay for military personnel and $485 million for an alternate engine for the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter. The President's FY2011 budget request included $738.7 billion for national defense. The FY2011 budget for the 050 function includes $733.3 billion in discretionary spending, with $5.3 billion in mandatory spending for military retirees. The Department of Defense requested $548.9 billion for regular operations and $159.3 billion for ongoing military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. Additionally, $33 billion was requested for supplemental DOD appropriations for FY2010 war costs. The requested supplemental funds for war costs in FY2011 would bring the total amount appropriated for FY2010 war costs to $162.6 billion. The budget request reflected a shift in emphasis from operations in Iraq to those in Afghanistan. An additional $655 million was requested for humanitarian relief operations in Haiti after the devastating earthquake. The FY2011 budget request includes a 3.4% increase in the DOD base budget, amounting to $548.9 billion, and a 1.8% "real growth" in purchasing power. Additionally, $719.2 billion is requested for security agencies, a 5.2% increase from FY2010, while non-security agencies would see a 1.5% decrease to $386.4 billion. The FY2011 budget request includes a 3.4% increase in the DOD base budget, totaling $548.9 billion. This would provide a 1.8% increase in real purchasing power after adjusting for inflation. The request continues the upward trend in DOD base budgets since FY1998. Defense Secretary Robert Gates highlighted the need for a 2% real growth rate to fund planned investments through FY2015. Secretary Gates aimed to sustain the current force and budgets by reducing DOD's overhead costs by $10 billion annually. He acknowledged the challenge of achieving the necessary real growth rates and proposed shifting funds within the budget to support combat forces while cutting spending on administrative and support activities. This approach, known as increasing the "tooth" while decreasing the "tail," aims to transfer savings to force structure and modernization. Secretary Gates announced initiatives to reduce DOD's overhead costs by $10 billion annually, aiming to shift funds to support combat forces and modernization. This approach involves increasing the "tooth" and decreasing the "tail" within the budget, with measures such as reducing funding for service support contractors, cutting the number of generals and admirals, and eliminating the Joint Forces Command. Secretary Gates announced initiatives to reduce DOD's overhead costs by $10 billion annually, aiming to shift funds to support combat forces and modernization. This involved reducing the number of senior DOD civilians by 150 over the next two years and eliminating various agencies. Additionally, contracting and acquisition initiatives were introduced to increase efficiency in DOD contracts for goods and services, with a focus on affordability targets and rewarding contractors for managing programs more efficiently. Some Members of Congress expressed concerns about the projected budget increases being inadequate given rising costs. Some Members of Congress express concerns about projected budget increases being inadequate due to rising costs. Representative Barney Frank calls for DOD budget reductions by terminating unnecessary weapons programs and scaling back overseas military deployments. President Obama's exemption of the military budget from deficit reduction efforts may lead to cuts in other federal programs. The FY2011 DOD base budget request amounts to 3.6% of the GDP, marking a leveling off of the DOD share of GDP since 9/11. The budget sustains previous initiatives and reflects the strategy outlined in the Quadrennial Defense Review. The 2010 Quadrennial Defense Review (QDR) emphasizes the shift towards diverse mission readiness for U.S. forces, prioritizing ongoing campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan. Recommendations include increased funding for helicopters, UAVs, intelligence capabilities, counter IED technologies, and AC-130 gunship aircraft. Long-term initiatives include converting one heavy Army brigade combat team (BCT). The 2010 Quadrennial Defense Review (QDR) focuses on converting one heavy Army brigade combat team into a Stryker brigade using wheeled armored vehicles. It anticipates potential adversaries challenging U.S. forces asymmetrically with unconventional tactics and technologies. The report dismisses the idea of a conflict spectrum and highlights the use of advanced technologies by both terrorist groups and near-peer competitors. The 2010 QDR emphasizes the importance of military operations in cyberspace, calling for enhanced capabilities to defend cyber-networks and collaborate with other agencies for cyber security. It also maintains the goal of being able to win two major regional wars simultaneously while emphasizing flexibility in responding to global threats. The 2010 QDR highlights the need for U.S. forces to handle multiple missions globally, including stabilizing countries, deterring aggressors, counter-insurgency, and disaster response. It also focuses on countering the "anti-access, area-denial" capabilities of potential adversaries like China and Iran, which could threaten U.S. power projection capabilities. The 2010 QDR emphasizes the importance of U.S. power projection capabilities in Europe, Asia, and other regions, despite the high cost. These capabilities are vulnerable to various attacks, such as ballistic missiles, cruise missiles, and submarines. The QDR suggests countering anti-access strategies by increasing reliance on long-range strike weapons and submarines. It also reflects an increase in active duty personnel compared to previous years, following a reduction in manpower since the 1990s. DOD officials argue that service members are currently better paid than 70% of private sector workers. Advocacy groups push for a higher raise to close the pay gap. Secretary Gates has opposed repeal pending completion of the study, but announced changes in enforcement procedures for the current law. The Bush and Obama administrations proposed fee increases for TRICARE beneficiaries, but Congress passed legislation to prevent them. The fleet is projected to grow to 315 ships by FY2020, peak at 320 ships in FY2024, then decline below 313 ships by FY2027. The plan faces challenges in maintaining required levels of attack submarines and cruiser-destroyer forces. The House passed a bill (H.R. 1) to fund federal agencies through FY2011, including $505.2 billion for base budget programs. The Senate debated H.R. 1 but laid it aside after failing to close debate. The Senate rejected an alternative funding measure by a vote of 42-58, offered by Senator Inouye, which would have provided $503.1 billion for base budget programs. The President signed an omnibus funding bill for the balance of FY2011, incorporating a detailed DOD appropriations bill similar to Inouye's provisions. The enacted bill provided $502.4 billion for the base budget and $677.7 billion for all DOD funding, including military construction and war costs, representing a $20.1 billion reduction from the President's request. The DOD appropriations bill incorporated $4.4 billion in reductions to the President's request, including cuts to prior year funds, Operations and Maintenance, Procurement, Research and Development, civilian pay, and FFRDCs. H.R. 1473 also added funds to the request in 226 instances, offsetting some of the cuts. Congressional earmarks in defense appropriations bills have decreased over the years. The FY2010 bill added significant amounts to the budget request, including funding for Navy strike fighters, equipment for the National Guard and reserve components, medical research programs, and Israeli missile defense systems. It also allocated funds for innovative research and procurement projects but did not continue development of an alternate engine for the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter. The bill funded a 1.4% military pay raise and added money for Military Career Advancement Accounts. The Senate committee bill added $162 million for Military Career Advancement Accounts (MyCAA) and $447.0 million for the Defense Health Program (DHP). It included increases for research programs focused on breast cancer, psychological health, and prostate cancer, while cutting funds for THAAD missile deployment. Additionally, $205 million was allocated to accelerate production of the Israeli Iron Dome system. President Obama requested funds for Iron Dome in FY2011, not included in the original DOD budget. H.R. 1473 provided $15.4 billion for Navy shipbuilding, with minor reductions. The bill reduced $1.38 billion for F-35 Joint Strike Fighters and $325.0 million for mid-air refueling tanker development. The winning firm was unlikely to spend the budgeted amount due to a delay in choosing between bidders. The bill denied funding for the Non-Line of Sight Missile and cut funds for the Ground Combat Vehicle program. The Army cancelled the NLOS Missile program and restarted the GCV competition in FY2011.
